results.headline: Strangers in a Land That’s Not So Strange
results.summary_short: “The Band’s Visit,” the first feature by the Israeli writer and director Eran Kolirin, flirts recklessly with obviousness, cuteness too.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Band's Visit

results.headline: A Career Circling Fame and the Drain
results.summary_short: As much the chronicle of an era as of a band, “The Holy Modal Rounders ... Bound to Lose” casts an affectionate eye on the kind of hedonism no one is meant to survive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Holy Modal Rounders

results.headline: The Young Bob Dylan, Charismatic and Electric
results.summary_short: If you were not at the Newport Folk Festival in the ’60s — or, for that matter, if you were — “The Other Side of the Mirror” places you in perfect seats.
results.display_title: The Other Side of the Mirror: Bob Dylan Live at the Newport Folk Festival, 1963-65

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Other Side of the Mirror: Bob Dylan Live at the Newport Folk Festival, 1963-65

results.headline: Putting Off the Pain of Grief by Starting on a Journey
results.summary_short: For most of its 85 minutes “Grace Is Gone,” a small, tender film about contemporary parenthood in wartime, carries off a delicate balancing act.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grace is Gone

results.headline: A Very Late Comeback
results.summary_short: Part tribute, part musical mystery, “ ’Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris” shines an overdue spotlight on a great who got away.
results.display_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris

results.headline: Crimes of the Naïve, Superficial Heart
results.summary_short: With “The Walker,” the director Paul Schrader likes his decadence ripe and toxic, seeping through the gold-trimmed furniture and into the water supply.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Walker

results.headline: Passionate Punches
results.summary_short: Not since “Thelma & Louise” (1991) and “Free Willy” (1993) has Michael Madsen played someone as huggable as the tragic hero of “Strength and Honor.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strength and Honor

results.headline: Big Foot Follies
results.summary_short: There’s precious little to laugh at in “The Sasquatch Gang,” a sad attempt to board the loser-nerd comedy bandwagon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sasquatch Gang

results.headline: From Jail to Dreamland, With Its Sadist in Briefs
results.summary_short: By turns clever, impassioned, incoherent and silly, “Revolver,” is a macho parable of a fallen man striving for grace.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revolver

results.headline: With Family
results.summary_short: “Dirty Laundry”is a back-to-your-roots film about a gay African-American named Sheldon who meets a young son (Aaron Grady Shaw) he didn’t know he had.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dirty Laundry

results.headline: Bless the Beasts and Children
results.summary_short: “The Golden Compass” has many of the virtues of a faithful screen adaptation and many of the predictable flaws.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Golden Compass

results.headline: A Devotion to Film Binds Two Loners
results.summary_short: In “Man in the Chair” Christopher Plummer, an actor typecast nowadays as a suave, smiling cobra, sheds his scales to play a tippling old curmudgeon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Man in the Chair

results.headline: Lies, Guilt, Stiff Upper Lips
results.summary_short: “Atonement” is an almost classical example of how pointless, how diminishing, the transmutation of literature into film can be.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Atonement

results.headline: About a Boy, His Village and Time in the Spotlight
results.summary_short: The documentary “Billy the Kid” presents the world according to a troubled teenager in Maine.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Billy the Kid

results.headline: Seeking Mr. and Mrs. Right for a Baby on the Way
results.summary_short: “Juno” respects the idiosyncrasies of its characters rather than exaggerating them or holding them up for ridicule.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Juno

results.headline: Songs in the Street, Revolution in the Air
results.summary_short: The tiny, tough, sneakily moving film “The Violin” wears its revolutionary romanticism on its sleeve, not far from its gun.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Violin

results.headline: Forget It, Jake, It’s Koreatown
results.summary_short: “Undoing,” by the writer and director Chris Chan Lee, buries a potentially haunting pulp thriller beneath flashy tics.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Undoing

results.headline: Come Back to Bollywood
results.summary_short: In “Aaja,” Madhuri Dixit, India’s biggest female star of the 1990s, reminds us that whatever “it” is, she’s still got it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aaja Nachle

results.headline: Down but Not Really Out
results.summary_short: If you are one of those who viewed Hayden Christensen’s portrayal of Anakin Skywalker as the ne plus ultra of lifelessness, prepare to be proven wrong with “Awake.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Awake

results.headline: Body Unwilling, a Mind Takes Flight
results.summary_short: With “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” Julian Schnabel demonstrates his own imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence.
results.display_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Diving Bell and the Butterfly
